channel.title: Portfolio website for Ignacio Pascale
channel.description: Recent content on Portfolio website for Ignacio Pascale

item.title: How do Americans behave on Social Media?
item.description: General Social Survey (GSS) How does the American Society relate to social media, technology and education? The General Social Survey (GSS) gathers data on American society in order to monitor and explain trends in attitudes, behaviours, and attributes. Many trends have been tracked for decades, so one can see the evolution of attitudes, etc in American Society. In this blog post, we analyze data from the 2016 GSS sample data, using it to estimate values of population parameters of interest about US adults.

item.title: How many bikes will be hired on a regular day on Summer?
item.description: Introduction In the following workshop I will analyse the data set londonBikes from the UK Government. I will try to build a model in which to quantify the relationship of hired bikes and some explanatory variables using regression analysis, and shortly after I will use that model to predict the number hirings for a regular day in London in Summer with more than 15 degrees Celcius. The workflow will proceed as follows:

item.title: How popular is Donald Trump?
item.description: Mr Donald Trump is undoubtely one of the most controversial persons in the world. Some people love him, others not so much. And there’s a lot going on about his approval index. But how popular is, in reality, Mr. President? fivethirtyeight.com has detailed data on all polls that track the president’s approval. You can find this information on the link. In this blogpost, we will download the data set approval_pollist to analyse Mr.

item.title: Mask Aceptance
item.description: NYT mask use Github source for data https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data/tree/master/mask-use Getting the data url <- "https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data/raw/master/mask-use/mask-use-by-county.csv" #nyt_mask_survey <- read_csv(here::here("data", "nyt_mask_survey.csv")) nyt_mask_survey <- read_csv(url) nyt_mask_survey <- nyt_mask_survey %>% clean_names() %>% mutate( mostly_yes= frequently+always, mostly_no = never+rarely, delta = mostly_yes-mostly_no ) glimpse(nyt_mask_survey) ## Rows: 3,142 ## Columns: 9 ## $ countyfp <chr> "01001", "01003", "01005", "01007", "01009", "01011", "010… ## $ never <dbl> 0.053, 0.083, 0.067, 0.020, 0.053, 0.031, 0.102, 0.152, 0.… ## $ rarely <dbl> 0.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
